page.title: 13LANDUSE SOUTH OF THE TOWN
page.content: This is an area of hills rising to 150 metres cut by the now dry valleys of rivers which may have flowed when the climate was wetter or when there were rivers of meltwater from the ice sheet near Hemel. The underlying rock is chalk with deposits of clay with flints on some hilltops nearly 3 metres thick. In these deposits are found lumps of the Hertfordshire pudding stone. The natural vegetation is grassland with clumps of deciduous trees known locally as 'hangers'. Soil varies, but much of the area is farmed.This is mostly arable with a rotation of cereal, cereal, oilseed rape. The latter crop is used for fodder and for the oil from its seed which makes soap, margarine and cooking oil. The crop has been subsidised by the E.E.C.There are some small dairy units.
